oai_dc:dc.dc:title: On sequences of integers of quadratic fields and computations
Über Folgen ganzer Elemente in quadratischen Körpern und Berechnungen
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Bircan, Nihal
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: ddc:5
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
In this thesis, we consider the integers $\alpha$ of the quadratic field $ \mathbb{Q} (\sqrt[]{d})$ where $d\in \Z$ is square-free and $d\equiv 1,2,3  mod 4$. Furthermore, let $p$ be an odd prime. Using the embedding into $ 	ext{GL}(2,\mathbb{R})$ we obtain bounds for the first $
u\in\N$ such that $\alpha^
u\equiv 1 mod p.$ For the conductor $f$, we then study the first integer $n=n(f)$ such that $\alpha^n\in\mathcal{O}_{f}$. We obtain bounds for $n(f)$ and for $n(fp^{k})$. We allow any norm $N(\alpha)
ot\eq 0$. A special case is that $\alpha$ is the fundamental unit $\varepsilon$ of the real quadratic field $ \mathbb{Q} (\sqrt[]{d})$. We consider matrices $A\in	ext{GL}(2,\mathbb{C})$ and we show how the integers $\alpha$ of any quadratic field $ \mathbb{Q} ( \sqrt[]{d})$ can be embedded in GL$(2,\mathbb{R})$ where $ d=4q+r\in \mathbb{Z} $. Namely, $A$ is defined by  egin{align*} A= 	ext{ }  egin{pmatrix} a&b \ bd&a \end{pmatrix}\ 	ext{for $ r=2,3$},\ \ A= egin{pmatrix} 	frac{1}{2} (a+b)&b \ qb&	frac{1}{2} (a-b) \end{pmatrix}\ 	ext{for } r=1. \end{align*} We are now interested in the $n$ such that $ A^{n} =I$ or $A^{n} =cI$ in the residue field $ \mathbb{Z}/ p\mathbb{Z} $ where $p$ is an odd prime. As a tool we use adapted Chebyshev polynomials $t_{n} (x;s)$ and $u_{n} (x;s)$, which are monic polynomials with integer coefficients. We can write the powers of an algebraic integer $\alpha$ as  egin{align*} \alpha ^{n} = egin{cases} 	ext{ } 	frac{1}{2} t_{n} (2a)+u_{n-1} (2a)b\sqrt{d} & 	ext{if } r=2,3\ 	frac{1}{2} t_{n} (a)+	frac{1}{2} u_{n-1} (a)b\sqrt{d} & 	ext{if } r=1. \end{cases}\end{align*} Let $s=$ det $A$ and $x=$ tr $A$. We obtain results about $ A^{n}$ for all $s
eq 0$. We formulate these results in terms of $t_{n} (x;s)=$ tr $A^{n}$. Now we consider again congruences modulo $p$. In the case of the quadratic field we have $s=N(\alpha)$. The Legendre symbol $\ell\coloneqq ((x^2 -4s)/p) $ will play an important role. The values of $n$ with $ A^{n}\equiv I  mod p$ are connected with $p-1$ if $\ell=+1$ and with $p+1$ if $\ell=-1$. In particular, we prove that if $s=1$ and $x^{2}-4
ot\equiv 0 mod p$ then $ t_{ rac{p-\ell}{2}} (x)\equiv 2((x+2)/p) mod p$ and to generalize this we determine the first $ n=(p-\ell)/2^{m}$ with $ t_{n} (x)\equiv 2 mod p$ in terms of a chain of Legendre symbols. We also consider the more complicated case $s=-1$ and prove similar results. In the last chapter we consider the asymptotic behaviour of $n(p)$ by large-scale computations. u}\in \mathcal{O}_{p}\}$. Our numerical results suggest that the frequencies should have a limit as the ranges of $d$ and $p$ tend simultaneously to infinity.
